[[Newark, New Jersey]], U.S. | origin = [[East Orange, New Jersey]] | instrument = Vocals, piano | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Dance music|dance]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[Gospel music|gospel]] | occupation = [[singer]], [[actress]], [[model (person)|model]], [[Film producer|producer]]http://www.filmbug.com/db/308 record producer,http://www.whitney-info.com/whitney-the-producer/ songwriter | years_active = 1977âpresent | label = [[Arista Records|Arista]]/[[Sony BMG]] (1983â2011)
[[RCA Records|RCA]] (2011âpresent) | associated_acts = [[Cissy Houston]], [[Dionne Warwick]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Bobby Brown]], [[Jermaine Jackson]], [[Enrique Iglesias]] | website = {{Official website|whitneyhouston.com}} }} '''Whitney Elizabeth Houston ''' (born August 9, 1963) is an American [[singer]], [[actress]], [[Film producer|producer]] and a former [[model (person)|model]]. Houston is the most awarded female act of all time, according to Guinness World Records,{{cite web|url=http://www.whitneyhouston.com/us/content/biography |title=Whitney Houston biography |publisher=whitneyhouston.com | date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2010-11-22}} and her [[List of awards and nominations received by Whitney Houston|list of awards]] include 2 [[Emmy Awards]], 6 [[Grammy Awards]], 30 [[Billboard Music Awards]], 22 [[American Music Awards]], among a total of 415 career awards as of 2010. Houston is also one of the world's [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists]], having sold over 170 million albums and singles worldwide.{{cite news|first=Alex |last=Dobuzinskis| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idUSTRE58D4Y020090915|title=Whitney Houston says she is "drug-free"|publisher=Reuters|date=September 15, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.whitneyhouston.com/us/biography|title=Whitney Houston Biography | publisher=whitneyhouston.com|date=|accessdate=January 12, 2010}} Inspired by several prominent soul singers in her family, including mother [[Cissy Houston]] and cousins [[Dionne Warwick]] and the late [[Dee Dee Warwick]], as well as her godmother, [[Aretha Franklin]], Houston began singing with [[New Jersey]] church's junior gospel choir at age 11.{{Cite journal |author= |url= http://books.google.com/books?id=prQDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA58&dq=whitney%20houston&pg=PA58#v=onepage&q&f=false | journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | title=Whitney Houston Sings Her Way to Stardom with Hit Album, Road Tour | page = 59 | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company | volume = 68 | issue = 24 | date = August 26, 1985 | accessdate = February 7, 2011 | issn = 0021-5996}} After she began performing alongside her mother in night clubs in the [[New York City]] area, she was discovered by [[Arista Records]] label head [[Clive Davis]]. As of 2011, Houston has released seven studio albums and three movie soundtrack albums, all of which have diamond, multi-platinum, platinum, or gold certification. Houston is the only artist to chart seven consecutive #1 ''Billboard'' Hot 100 hits ("Saving All My Love for You", "How Will I Know", "Greatest Love of All", "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)", "Didn't We Almost Have It All", "So Emotional", and "Where Do Broken Hearts Go"). Houston is the second artist behind Elton John and the only female artist to have two number-one Top ''Billboard 200'' Album awards (formerly "Top Pop Album") on the ''Billboard'' magazine year-end charts. Houston's 1985 debut album, ''[[Whitney Houston (album)|Whitney Houston]]'', became the best-selling debut album by a female act at the time of its release. The album was also named ''Rolling Stone''{{'}}s best album of 1986, and was ranked at number 254 on ''Rolling Stone''{{'}}s list of the [[500 Greatest Albums of All Time]].{{cite web| first = Steve|last= Huey | title = Whitney Houston biography | publisher = [[Allmusic|Allmusic.com]] | year = 2006 | url = http://www.allmusic.com/artist/whitney-houston-p4519/biography | accessdate = April 13, 2009 | postscript = }} Her second studio album, ''[[Whitney (album)|Whitney]]'' (1987), became the first album by a female artist to debut at number one on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] albums chart. Houston's crossover appeal on the popular music charts as well as her prominence on [[MTV]], starting with her video for "[[How Will I Know]]",{{cite journal | author = | journal = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | url = http://books.google.com/?id=ESUEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA59&dq=1986%20mtv%20video%20music%20awards%20whitney%20houston&pg=PA59#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title = The 1986 MTV Video Music Awards The Winners! | publisher = Nielsen Business Media, Inc. | volume = 98 | issue = 41 | date = October 11, 1986 | accessdate = February 7, 2011 | issn = 0006-2510}} influenced several African-American female artists to follow in her footsteps.{{cite news| first= Richard | last= Corliss | title= The Prom Queen of Soul |date=July 13, 1987| publisher= [[Time Inc.]] | url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,964980,00.html| accessdate= March 17, 2007 }}{{cite episode |title = A History of Soul Music |network =[[VH1]]|airdate=October 18, 2007}} Houston's first acting role was as the star of the feature film ''[[The Bodyguard]]'' (1992). The movie's [[The Bodyguard: Original Soundtrack Album|original soundtrack]] won the 1994 [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year]]. Its lead single, "[[I Will Always Love You]]", became the [[List of best-selling singles worldwide|best-selling single]] by a female artist in music history. With this album, Houston became the first act (solo or group, male or female) to sell more than a million copies of an album within a single week period. The album also makes her the only female act in the top 10 list of the best-selling albums of all time, at number four. Houston continued to star in movies and contribute to their adjoining soundtracks, including the films ''[[Waiting to Exhale]]'' (1995) and ''[[The Preacher's Wife]]'' (1996). ''[[The Preacher's Wife: Original Soundtrack Album|The Preacher's Wife]]'' soundtrack would go on to become the best-selling gospel album in history.{{cite web| title = Whitney Houston Biography | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/whitney-houston/biography | accessdate = March 17, 2011 | work = [[Rolling Stone]]| postscript = }} Three years after the release of her fourth studio album, ''[[My Love Is Your Love]]'' (1998), she renewed her recording contract with [[Arista Records]]. She released her fifth studio album, ''[[Just Whitney]]'', in 2002, and the [[Christmas]]-themed ''[[One Wish: The Holiday Album]]'' in 2003. Amid widespread media coverage of personal and professional turmoil, Houston ended her 14-year marriage to singer [[Bobby Brown]] in 2006. In 2009, Houston released her seventh studio album, ''[[I Look to You]]''. ==Biography== ===1963â76: Early life=== Whitney Houston was born in what was then a middle-income neighbourhood of [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], [[New Jersey]], the third and youngest child of John and gospel singer [[Cissy Houston]].{{cite episode |title = Whitney Houston |series = Driven |network = [[VH1]] |airdate = November 13, 2002}} She is mostly [[African-American]], with some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native-American]] and [[Dutch people|Dutch]] ancestry. Her mother, along with cousins [[Dionne Warwick]] and the late [[Dee Dee Warwick]] and godmother [[Aretha Franklin]] were all notable figures in the gospel, rhythm and blues, pop, and [[soul music|soul]] genres. Houston was raised a [[Baptist]], but was also exposed to the [[Pentecostal]] church. After the [[1967 Newark riots]], the family moved to a middle class area in [[East Orange, New Jersey]] when she was four. At the age of eleven, Houston began to follow in her mother's footsteps and started performing as a soloist in the junior gospel choir at the New Hope Baptist Church in Newark, where she also learned to play the piano.{{Cite news| title= Whitney & Bobby â Addicted to Love |date=September 2005| publisher= Vibe Magazine | url= http://www.classicwhitney.com/interview/vibe_sep2005.htm| accessdate= March 17, 2007 }} Her first solo performance in the church was "Guide Me, O Thou Great Jehovah".{{Cite journal | author = | url= http://books.google.com/books?id=lLQDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA58&vq=WHITNEY&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA59#v=onepage&q&f=false | journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | page = 59 | title = Whitney Houston Tells what God Gave Her | publisher= Johnson Publishing Company | volume = 69 | issue = 22 | date=February 17, 1986|accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}} When Houston was a teenager, she attended a Catholic girls high school, [[Mount Saint Dominic Academy]], where she met her best friend Robyn Crawford, whom she describes as the "sister she never had."Staff. [http://books.google.com/books?id=qyYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA78 "Too Cool for School"], ''[[Vibe (magazine)]]'', p. 78, June 2007. Accessed April 18, 2011. "Whitney Houston as a senior at Mount Saint Dominic Academy, Caldwell, NJ, 1981." While Houston was still in school, her mother continued to teach her how to sing. In addition to her mother, Franklin, and Warwick, Houston was also exposed to the music of [[Chaka Khan]], [[Gladys Knight]], and [[Roberta Flack]], most of whom would have an impact on her as a singer and performer.{{Cite news| first= Anthony | last= DeCurtis | title= Whitney Houston: Down and Dirty | date=June 10, 1993| publisher= ''[[Rolling Stone]]''; Jann S. Wenner, editor and publisher | url= http://www.classicwhitney.com/interview/rollingstone_1993.htm| accessdate= March 17, 2007 }} ===1977â84: Early career=== Houston spent some of her teenage years touring nightclubs where her mother Cissy was performing, and she would occasionally get on stage and perform with her. In 1977, at age 14, she became a backup singer on the [[Michael Zager Band]]'s single "Life's a Party". Zager subsequently offered to obtain a recording contract for the young singer, but Cissy declined, wanting her daughter to finish school first. Then in 1978, at age 15, Houston sang background vocals on [[Chaka Khan]]'s hit single "[[I'm Every Woman]]", a song she would later turn into a larger hit for herself on her monster-selling ''[[The Bodyguard: Original Soundtrack Album|The Bodyguard]]'' soundtrack album. She also sang back-up on albums by [[Lou Rawls]] and [[Jermaine Jackson]]. In the early 1980s, Houston started working as a fashion model after a photographer saw her at [[Carnegie Hall]] singing with her mother. She appeared as a lead vocalist on a [[Paul Jabara]] album, entitled ''[[Paul Jabara & Friends|Paul Jabara and Friends]]'', released by [[Columbia Records]] in 1983.{{cite web|first=Vince |last=Ripol|url=http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:hbftxqrgldje|title=Paul Jabara & Friends Album Review|publisher=Allmusic|date=|accessdate=January 14, 2010}} She appeared in ''[[Seventeen (magazine)|Seventeen]]''{{Cite news| first= Joy | last= Duckett Cain | title= The Soul of Whitney |date=December 2023| publisher= Essence Magazine | url= http://www.classicwhitney.com/interview/essence_1990.htm| accessdate= February 15, 2008}} and became one of the first women of color to grace the cover of the magazine.{{cite web| last = Traister |first = Rebecca |title = Didn't She Almost Have It All |publisher = Salon.com | date = April 13, 2006 |url = http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2006/04/12/whitney_houston/index.html |accessdate = December 12, 2007}} She was also featured in layouts in the pages of ''[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]'', ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'', ''Young Miss'', and appeared in a [[Canada Dry]] soft drink TV commercial.{{Cite journal | journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |author = |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Ra8DAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA32&vq=whitney&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA32#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Singer Whitney Houston a Model of Success| page = 32 | publisher= Johnson Publishing Company |volume = 78 | issue = 14 | date=July 16, 1990|accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}} Her striking looks and girl-next-door charm made her one of the most sought after teen models of that time. While modeling, she continued her burgeoning recording career by working with producers Ben Dover, [[Bill Laswell]] and [[Martin Bisi]] on an album they were spearheading called ''One Down'', which was credited to the group [[Material (band)|Material]]. For that project, Houston contributed the ballad "Memories". Robert Christgau of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' called her contribution "one of the most gorgeous ballads you've ever heard."{{cite web| last = Christgau |first = Robert | authorlink = Robert Christgau |title = Material she was a great song writer|publisher = RobertChristgau.com | url = http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist.php?name=Material|accessdate = December 12, 2007}} Houston had previously been offered several recording agencies (Michael Zager in 1980, and [[Elektra Records]] in 1981). In 1983, Gerry Griffith, an A&R representative from [[Arista Records]] saw her performing with her mother in a New York City nightclub and was impressed. He convinced Arista's head [[Clive Davis]] to make time to see Houston perform. Davis too was impressed and offered a worldwide recording contract which Houston signed. Later that year, she made her national televised debut alongside Davis on ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]''.{{Cite journal | author = | journal = [[Ebony (magazine)|EBONY]] | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=JtkDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA155&dq=whitney%20houston&pg=PA155#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Whitney Houston For Talented Young Star, Singing Is A Family Tradition |publisher= Johnson Publishing Company | volume = 40 | issue = 12 | date=December, 1985|accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0012-9011}} Houston signed with Arista in 1983 but did not begin work on her album immediately. The label wanted to make sure no other label signed the singer away. Davis wanted to ensure he had the right material and producers for Houston's debut album. Some producers had to pass on the project due to prior commitments.{{Cite news|first=Bud|last=Scoppa|title=The Long Road To Overnight Stardom|date=December 1986|publisher= Billboard Magazine" The Year In Rock '86|url=http://www.classicwhitney.com/interview/billboard1986artistoftheyear.htm| accessdate= March 17, 2007}} Houston first recorded a duet with [[Teddy Pendergrass]] entitled "[[Hold Me (Teddy Pendergrass & Whitney Houston song)|Hold Me]]" which appeared on his album, ''[[Love Language]]''.{{cite web|first=Ron | last=Wynn |url=http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:d9fwxqr5ld6e|title=''Love Language'' Album Review|publisher=Allmusic|date=|accessdate=January 14, 2010}} The single was released in 1984 and gave Houston her first taste of success, becoming a Top 5 R&B hit. It would also appear on her debut album in 1985. ===1985â86: Rise to international prominence=== With production from [[Michael Masser]], [[Kashif (musician)|Kashif]], [[Jermaine Jackson]], and [[Narada Michael Walden]], Houston's debut album ''[[Whitney Houston (album)|Whitney Houston]]'' was released in February 1985. ''Rolling Stone'' magazine praised Houston, calling her "one of the most exciting new voices in years" while ''The New York Times'' called the album "an impressive, musically conservative showcase for an exceptional vocal talent."{{cite web| first= Don | last= Shewey | title= Music Review: ''Whitney Houston'' | date = June 6, 1985| publisher= ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/whitney-houston-19850606| accessdate= March 17, 2011 }}{{Cite news| last = Holden | first = Stephen | title = Critic's Choice; Pop Music | newspaper = New York Times | pages = A2 | publisher = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | date = May 12, 1985 | accessdate =March 5, 2008 }} Arista Records promoted Houston's album with three different singles from the album in the US, UK and other European countries. In the UK, the dance-funk "Someone for Me", failed to chart in the country, was the first single while "[[All at Once (Whitney Houston song)|All at Once]]" was in such European countries as the [[Netherlands]] and [[Belgium]], where the song reached top 5 on the singles charts, respectively.{{cite journal | author = Kim Freeman | url = http://books.google.co.kr/books?id=8yQEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA4&lr&hl=en&rview=1&pg=PT54#v=onepage&q&f=false | journal = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | title = Whitney Houston's Success Is Global | publisher = Nielsen Business Media, Inc. | volume = 97 | issue = 23 | date = June 8, 1985 | accessdate = March 15, 2011 | issn = 0006-2510}} In the US, the soulful Ballad "[[You Give Good Love]]" was chosen as the [[lead single]] from Houston's debut to establish her in the black marketplace first.{{cite news | author = Paul Grein | url = http://articles.latimes.com/1986-06-08/entertainment/ca-9249_1/3 | title = Houston Hits: Master Plan, Blind Luck | publisher = [[Tribune Company]] | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = June 8, 1986 | accessdate = October 28, 2011}} Outside the US, the song failed to get enough attention to become a hit but in the US, gave the album its first major hit as it peaked at #3 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart, and #1 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Hot R&B]] chart. As a result, the album began to sell strongly, and Houston continued promotion by touring nightclubs in the US. She also began performing on late-night television talk shows, which were not usually accessible to unestablished black acts. The jazzy ballad "[[Saving All My Love for You]]" was released next and it would become Houston's first #1 single in both the US and the UK. She was now an opening act for singer [[Jeffrey Osborne]] on his nationwide tour. "Thinking About You" was released as the promo single only to R&B-oriented radio stations, which peaked at number ten of the US R&B Chart. At the time, MTV had received harsh criticism for not playing enough videos by black, latin, and other racial minorities while favoring white acts.{{cite episode|title=Whitney Houston|Series=Headliners And Legends|serieslink=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3036702/|airdate = August 11, 2000|season=|number=}} The third US single, "[[How Will I Know]]," peaked at #1 and introduced Houston to the MTV audience thanks to its video. Houston's subsequent singles from this, and future albums, would make her the first African-American female artist to receive consistent heavy rotation on MTV. By 1986, a year after its initial release, ''Whitney Houston'' topped the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] albums chart and stayed there for 14 non-consecutive weeks.{{cite journal | journal = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | url = http://books.google.co.kr/books?id=tiQEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA1&hl=en&pg=PA52#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = 1986 Overview: Charts | publisher = Nielsen Business Media, Inc. | volume = 98 | issue = 52 | date = December 27, 1986 | accessdate = March 17, 2011 | issn = 0006-2510}} The final single, "[[Greatest Love of All]]," became Houston's biggest hit at the time after peaking #1 and remaining there for three weeks on the Hot 100 chart, which made her debut the first album by a female artist to yield three #1 hits. Houston was #1 artist of the year and ''Whitney Houston'' was the #1 album of the year on 1986 ''Billboard'' year-end charts, making her the first female artist to earn that distinction. At the time, Houston released the best-selling debut album by a solo artist.{{cite web|url=http://riaa.org/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=tblTop100 |title=Gold & Platinum >> Top 100 Albums |publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |date= |accessdate=June 13, 2010}} Houston then embarked on her world tour, ''[[Greatest Love Tour]]''. The album had become an international success, and was certified 13× platinum (diamond) in the United States alone, and has sold a total of 25 million copies worldwide.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH|title=RIAA Certification Searchable Database|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |date=July 29, 1999|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} At the [[28th Grammy Awards|1986 Grammy Awards]], Houston was nominated for three awards including [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year#1980s|Album of the Year]].{{cite journal | author=|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NrMDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA57&vq=whitney&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA57#v=onepage&q&f=false | journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | title=Tina, Whitney Top Picks for Annual Grammy Awards | page = 57 | publisher=Johnson Publishing Company | volume = 69 | issue = 19 | date=January 27, 1986|accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}} She was not eligible for the [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] category due to her previous hit R&B duet recording with Teddy Pendergrass in 1984.{{cite news| first= Richard | last= Harrington | title= Dire Straits Tops List for Grammy's; We are the World Wins 6 Nominations|date=January 10, 1986| publisher= The Washington Post| accessdate= March 17, 2007 }} She won her first [[Grammy]] award for [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance|Best Pop Vocal Performance, Female]] for "Saving All My Love for You".{{cite journal |author=| journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=CrQDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA14&vq=whitney&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA14#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = 'We are the World' Big Winner at 28th Grammys | page = 14 | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company | volume = 69 | issue = 26 | date = March 17, 1986 | accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}} At the same award show, she performed that Grammy-winning hit; that performance later winning her an [[Emmy]] Award for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Individual Performance in a Variety or Music Program|Outstanding Individual Performance in a Variety or Music Program]].{{Cite journal | journal = [[jet (magazine)|Jet]] | author = | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=5LADAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA16&vq=whitney&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA16#v=onepage&q&f=false | title='Cosby Show' Snubbed at Emmy Awards Ceremony; Receives Only One Honor | page = 16 | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company | volume = 71 | issue = 4 | date=October 13, 1986|accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}} Houston won seven [[American Music Awards]] in total in 1986 and 1987, and an [[MTV Video Music Award]].{{Cite journal | journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | author = | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=lLQDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA58&vq=whitney&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA56#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = Whitney, Aretha, Stevie Snare Honors at Recent American Music Awards | page = 56 | volume = 69 | issue = 22 | publisher= Johnson Publishing Company | date= February 17, 1986| accessdate = January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}}{{Cite journal | journal = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | first=Aldore|last= Collier|url = http://books.google.com/books?id=wLMDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA58&vq=whitney&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA58#v=onepage&q&f=false| title = Whitney Houston: Why Success Won't Go to Her Head | page = 58 | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company'| volume = 71 | issue = 21 | date= February 16, 1987| accessdate=January 12, 2010 | issn = 0021-5996}} The album's popularity would also carry over to the [[29th Grammy Awards|1987 Grammy Awards]] when "Greatest Love of All" would receive a [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year#1980s|Record of the Year]] nomination. Houston's debut album is listed as one of ''Rolling Stone''{{'}}s [[500 Greatest Albums of All Time]] and on [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame|The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame]]'s Definitive 200 list.{{cite news| url = http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/500-greatest-albums-of-all-time-19691231/whitney-houston-whitney-houston-19691231 | title= The Rolling Stone 500 Greatest Albums of All Time | 2008}} Whitney Houston's grand entrance into the music industry is considered one of the 25 musical milestones of the last 25 years, according to ''[[USA Today]]''.{{cite news| last=Gundersen | first=Edna | title=25 years of memorable musical moments | publisher=''[[USA Today]]'' |url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/top25-musicmoments.htm?csp=34| accessdate = January 1, 2008 | date=June 18, 2007}} Following Houston's breakthrough, doors were opened for other African-American female artists such as [[Janet Jackson]] and [[Anita Baker]] to find notable success in popular music and on MTV.{{cite news| last = Rizzo | first = Frank | title = Houston Tops New Wave of Women With Pop Punch Aplenty | newspaper = Orlando Sentinel | page = 11 | publisher = Orlando Sentinel | date = August 30, 1987 |accessdate =March 5, 2008 }}{{cite news| last = Hunt | first = Dennis | title = Anita Baker: 'Most Powerful Black Woman Singer of 80s' | newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle| page = 44 | publisher = San Francisco Chronicle | date = February 1, 1987 |accessdate =March 5, 2008 }} ===1987â91: ''Whitney'', ''I'm Your Baby Tonight'' and "The Star Spangled Banner"=== With many expectations Houstonâs second album, ''[[Whitney (album)|Whitney]]'', was released in June 1987. The album again featured production from Masser, Kashif and Walden as well as [[Jellybean Benitez]]. Many critics complained that the material was too similar to her previous album. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' said, "the narrow channel through which this talent has been directed is frustrating."{{cite web | first = Vince |last=Aletti | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/whitney-19870813 | title = Review: ''Whitney'' | publisher = [[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media, LLC]] | date = August 13, 1987 | accessdate = March 16, 2011}} Still, the album enjoyed commercial success. Houston became the first female artist in music history to debut at number one on the ''Billboard'' 200 albums chart, and the first artist to enter the albums chart at number one in both the US and UK, while also hitting number one or top ten in dozens of other countries around the world. The album's first single, "[[I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me)]]," was also a massive hit worldwide, peaking at #1 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart and topping the singles chart in many countries such as Australia, Germany and the UK. | publisher = [[Prometheus Global Media]] | date = December 17, 2001 | accessdate = October 29, 2011}} ===2000â05: ''Just Whitney'', and personal struggles=== Though Houston was seen as a "good girl" with a perfect image in the '80s and early '90s, by the late '90s, her behavior changed. She was often hours late for interviews, photo shoots and rehearsals, and canceling concerts and talk-show appearances.[http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/whitneyhouston/biography Whitney Houston Biography], ''Rolling Stone'' (last visited February 15, 2008).Larry McShane, [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/digest/ent3.htm "Whitney Houston Gets Bad Press"], ''Washington Post'', April 6, 2000. With the missed performances and weight loss, rumors about Houston using drugs with her husband circulated. On January 11, 2000, airport security guards discovered marijuana in both Houston's and husband Bobby Brown's luggage at a Hawaii airport, but the two boarded the plane and departed before authorities could arrive. Charges were later dropped against her and Brown,TCM Breaking News, [http://archives.tcm.ie/breakingnews/2001/09/11/story23275.asp "Fears for Whitney Houston Grow"], September 11, 2001. but rumors of drug usage between the couple would continue to surface. Two months later, Clive Davis was inducted into the [[Rock & Roll Hall of Fame]]. Houston had been scheduled to perform at the event, but did not attend.Andrew Dansby, [http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/whitneyhouston/articles/story/5924161/whitney_insider_tells_of_drug_use_failed_intervention "Whitney Insider Tells of Drug Use, Failed Intervention"], ''Rolling Stone'', June 7, 2000. Shortly thereafter, Houston was scheduled to perform at the Academy Awards but was fired from the event by musical director and long time friend [[Burt Bacharach]]. Her publicist cited throat problems as the reason for the cancellation. In his book ''The Big Show: High Times and Dirty Dealings Backstage at the Academy Awards'', author Steve Pond revealed that "Houston's voice was shaky, she seemed distracted and jittery, and her attitude was casual, almost defiant," and that while Houston was to sing "[[Over the Rainbow]]", she would start singing a different song.Movie & TV News @ IMDB.com, [http://www.imdb.com/news/wenn/2004-12-23#celeb5 "Houston's Oscar Confusion"], December 23, 2004. Houston was replaced at that Oscar telecast by singer Faith Hill. Houston later admitted to having been fired.[[Diane Sawyer]], Interview, ABC Primetime, December 4, 2002 (transcript available at [http://www.whitney-fan.com/nr/tv/015.shtml whitney-fan.com]). Later that year, Houston's long-time executive assistant and friend, Robyn Crawford, resigned from Houston's management company. In August 2001, Houston signed the biggest record deal in music history with Arista/[[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]]. She renewed her contract for $100 million to deliver six new albums, on which she would also earn royalties.{{cite web|first=Robert|last= Lafranco with Mark Binelli and Fred Goodman|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5938443/the_rolling_stone_money_report|title=The Rolling Stone Money Report: The pop stars who earned the most last year â and how they did it|publisher= [[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media, LLC]] |date=July 4, 2002|accessdate=January 15, 2010}}{{Cite book|author=|url=http://books.google.com/?id=BbUDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA18&dq=whitney+houston+%24100+million+contract&cd=1#v=onepage&q=whitney%20houston%20%24100%20million%20contract|title= Whitney Houston Signs $100 Million Contract with Arista Records (p18)|publisher=''[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]''|date=August 20, 2001|accessdate=January 12, 2010}}{{cite journal | journal = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | first=Gail|last= Mitchell|url=http://books.google.com/?id=MQ0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA1&dq=whitney+houston+%24100+million+contract+six+albums&cd=3#v=onepage&q=|title=Arista Aims New Houston Album At 'Core Urban' Fans| publisher = Nielson Business Media, Inc. |date=December 14, 2002|accessdate=January 12, 2010}} She later made an appearance on ''[[Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Special]]''. Her extremely thin frame further spurred rumors of drug use. Houston's publicist said, "Whitney has been under stress due to family matters, and when she is under stress she doesn't eat."{{Cite news| first= Sharon | last= Knolle | title= Reports of Whitney Houston's Death Denied |date=September 13, 2001 | publisher= ABC News | url= http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=102477&page=1| accessdate= March 17, 2007 }} The singer was scheduled for a second performance the following night but canceled.Lynette Holloway, [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9406E2D91231F932A25752C1A9649C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=print "In Switch, Whitney Houston Has to Sell an Album"], ''New York Times'', November 11, 2002. Within weeks, Houston's rendition of "The Star Spangled Banner" would be re-released after the terrorist attacks of September 11. The song peaked at #6 this time on the US Hot 100, topping its previous position. Houston donated her portion of the proceeds. In 2002, Houston became involved in a legal dispute with John Houston Enterprise. Although the company was started by her father to manage her career, it was now actually run by company president Kevin Skinner. Skinner filed a [[breach-of-contract]] [[lawsuit]] and sued for $100 million (but lost), stating that Houston owed the company previously unpaid compensation for helping to negotiate her $100 million contract with Arista Records and for sorting out legal matters.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1458015/20021008/houston_whitney.jhtml?headlines=true |title=Whitney Houston Sued For $100 Million By Dad's Company |accessdate=January 15, 2008 |work=MTV.com |date=October 8, 2002}} Houston stated that her 81-year-old father had nothing to do with the lawsuit. Although Skinner tried to claim otherwise, John Houston never appeared in court.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_19_102/ai_93457202 |title=Whitney Houston is sued for $100 million by her father's entertainment company â Entertainment |accessdate=January 15, 2008 |work=Jet Magazine |date=October 28, 2002}} Houston's father later died in February 2003.Friedman, Roger. [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,78063,00.html Whitney and Bobby No-Shows at Dad's Funeral] FOXNews.com. February 10, 2003 The lawsuit was dismissed on April 5, 2004, and Skinner was awarded nothing.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3628169.stm |title=Judge throws out Houston lawsuit |accessdate=January 15, 2008 |work=BBC News |date=April 15, 2004}} Also in 2002, Houston did an interview with [[Diane Sawyer]] to promote her then-upcoming album. The interview was the highest-rated television interview in history. During the prime-time special, Houston spoke on topics including rumored drug use and marriage. She was asked about the ongoing drug rumors and replied, "First of all, let's get one thing straight. [[Crack cocaine|Crack]] is cheap. I make too much money to ever smoke crack. Let's get that straight. Okay? We don't do crack. We don't do that. Crack is wack." The line would become infamous.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14824108/|title=Whitney Houston, Bobby Brown separate|date=September 13, 2006|publisher=msnbc.msn.com|accessdate=October 5, 2008}} Houston did, however, admit to using other substances at times. In December 2002, Houston released her fifth studio album, ''[[Just Whitney...]]''. The album included productions from then-husband [[Bobby Brown]], as well as Missy Elliott and Babyface, and marked the first time Houston did not produce with [[Clive Davis]] as Davis had been released by top management at BMG. Upon its release, ''Just Whitney...'' received mixed reviews.MetaCritic.com, [http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/houstonwhitney/justwhitney "Just Whitney" by Whitney Houston] (last visited February 15, 2008). The album debuted at number 9 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart and it had the highest first week sales of any album Houston had ever released.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/retrieve_chart_history.do?model.chartFormatGroupName=Albums&model.vnuArtistId=4849&model.vnuAlbumId=556398 |title=Music News, Reviews, Articles, Information, News Online & Free Music |publisher=Billboard.com |date= |accessdate=June 13, 2010}} The four singles released from the album, didn't fare well on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, but became [[Hot Dance Club Play]] hits. ''Just Whitney...'' was certified [[RIAA certification|platinum]] in the United States, and sold approximately three million worldwide.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH|title=RIAA Certification Searchable Database|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]|date=January 10, 2003|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} In late 2003, Houston released her first Christmas album ''[[One Wish: The Holiday Album]]'', with a song listing of traditional holiday songs. Houston produced the album with [[Mervyn Warren]] and Gordon Chambers. A single titled "[[One Wish (for Christmas)]]" reached the Top 20 on the Adult Contemporary chart, and the album was certified gold in the US. Having always been a touring artist, Houston spent most of 2004 touring and performing in [[Europe]], the [[Middle East]], [[Asia]], and [[Russia]]. In September 2004, she gave a surprise performance at the [[World Music Awards]], in tribute to long time friend [[Clive Davis]]. After the show, Davis and Houston announced plans to go into studio to work on her new album.Paul Cashmere, [http://www.whitney-houston.com/news/articles/180904a.htm "Whitney Back With Clive Davis"], Pops by Paul Cashmere, September 17, 2004, available at whitney-houston.com. In early 2004, husband Bobby Brown starred in his own reality TV program, ''[[Being Bobby Brown]]'' (on the [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo network]]), which provided a view into the domestic goings-on in the Brown household. Though it was Brown's vehicle, Houston was a prominent figure throughout the show, receiving as much screen time as Brown. The series aired in 2005 and featured Houston in, what some would say, not her most flattering moments. The ''Hollywood Reporter'' said it was "undoubtedly the most disgusting and execrable series ever to ooze its way onto television."Barry Garron, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/8409211/ "'Being Bobby Brown' Is Disgusting"], MSNBC, July 7, 2005. Despite the perceived train-wreck nature of the show, the series gave Bravo its highest ratings in its time slot and continued Houston's successful forays into film and television.Steve Rogers, [http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/report-bravo-being-bobby-brown-coming-back-for-second-season-3794.php "Report: Bravo's 'Being Bobby Brown' coming back for second season"], RealityTV World, October 31, 2005. The show was not renewed for a second season after Houston stated she would no longer appear in it, and Brown and Bravo could not come to an agreement for another season.[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/sfgate/detail?blogid=7&entry_id=12515 "Brown Reality Show Cancelled"], ''SFGate'', The Daily Dish, January 10, 2007. ===2006âpresent: Return to music, ''I Look to You'', tour and film comeback=== After years of controversy and turmoil, Houston separated from Bobby Brown in September 2006, filing for divorce the next month.{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,213689,00.html|title=Whitney Houston Files for Divorce From Bobby Brown|date=September 13, 2006|agency=Associated Press | work=Fox News}} On February 1, 2007, Houston asked the court to [[fast track]] their divorce.{{Cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2007-02-01-whitney-houston_x.htm|title=Whitney wants to speed up her divorce|date=February 1, 2007|publisher=usatoday.com|accessdate=October 5, 2008}} The divorce was finalized on April 24, 2007, with Houston granted custody of the couple's daughter.{{Cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20033741,00.html|title=Whitney Houston Wins Custody in Divorce From Bobby Brown|last=Breuer|first=Howard |coauthors=Keith, Amy|date=April 5, 2007|publisher=People|accessdate=October 5, 2008}} Less than a month later, Brown sued Houston in [[Orange County, California]] court in an attempt to change the terms of their custody agreement. Brown also sought child and spousal support from Houston. In the lawsuit, Brown claimed that financial and emotional problems prevented him from properly responding to Houston's divorce petition.{{Cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20038695,00.html|title=Bobby Brown Sues Whitney Houston for Custody, Spousal Support|last=Keith|first=Amy Elisa |date=May 11, 2007|publisher=People|accessdate=October 5, 2008}} Brown lost at his court hearing as the judge dismissed his appeal to overrule the custody terms, leaving Houston with full custody and Brown with no spousal support.[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/sfgate/detail?blogid=7&entry_id=23236 Brown Cannot Overturn Houston Divorce Terms After Court No-Show], "The Daily Dish!", ''SFGate'', January 7, 2008. In March 2007, Clive Davis of Arista Records announced that Houston would begin recording a new album.{{cite news|first=Roger |last=Friedman| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,258421,00.html|title=Whitney Houston Starts Work on New Album Today|publisher=''[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]''|date=March 13, 2007|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} In October 2007, Arista released another compilation ''[[The Ultimate Collection (Whitney Houston album)|The Ultimate Collection]]'' outside the United States.{{cite web | author = | url = http://www.amazon.co.uk/Whitney-Houston-Ultimate-Collection/dp/B000WAEJZ0/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1300371753&sr=8-1 | title = Whitney Houston - The Ultimate Collection (CD) | publisher = [[Amazon.com|Amazon.com, Inc]] | date = October 29, 2007 | accessdate = March 17, 2011}} Houston released her new album, ''[[I Look to You]]'', on August 2009.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-06-09-voa47.cfm|title=Whitney Houston Album Due Out Sept. 1; 'American Idol' Auditions Kick Off|publisher=''[[Voice of America|VOA News]]''|date=June 9, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} The album's first two singles are "I Look to You" and "Million Dollar Bill". The album entered the [[Billboard 200]] at #1, with Houston's best opening-week sales of 305,000 copies, marking Houston's first number one album since '' The Bodyguard '', and Houston's first studio album to reach number one since 1987's ''[[Whitney (album)|Whitney]]''. Houston gave her first interview in seven years, appearing on Oprah Winfrey's season premiere on September 2009. The interview was billed as "the most anticipated music interview of the decade".[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/08/20/entertainment/main5255493.shtml "Whitney Houston to Tell All On Oprah"]. [[CBS]]. August 20, 2009. The interview was so candid that Whitney admitted using drugs with former husband [[Bobby Brown]] describing to [[Oprah]] that she "laced marijuana with rock cocaine".{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/story/houston-details-drug-use-we-laced-marijuana-with-rock-cocaine_1116018 |title=Whitney Houston - Houston Details Drug Use: 'We Laced Marijuana With Rock Cocaine' - Contactmusic News |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date=2009-09-15 |accessdate=2010-11-11}} Houston has also appeared on European television programs to promote the album. She performed the song "I Look to You" on the German television show ''Wetten Dass.'' Three days later, she performed the worldwide first single from I Look To You, [[Million Dollar Bill]], on the French television show Le Grand Journal. Houston appeared as guest mentor on ''[[The X Factor (UK series 6)|The X Factor]]'' in the United Kingdom. She performed "Million Dollar Bill" on the following day's results show, completing the song even as a strap in the back of her dress popped open two minutes into the performance. She later commented that she "sang [herself] out of [her] clothes". Houston appeared on the Italian version of X Factor, performing the same song "Million Dollar Bill" to good reviews.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} She was awarded the Gold Certificate for achieving over 50,000 CD sales of "I Look To You" in Italy.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.whitneyhouston.com/us/news/whitney-conquers-italy-again|title=Whitney Conquers Italy â Again!|publisher=whitneyhouston.com|date=October 21, 2009|accessdate=January 12, 2010}} In November, Houston performed "I Didn't Know My Own Strength" at the 2009 American Music Awards in Los Angeles, California. However, some poor reviews and rescheduled concerts brought some negative media attention.{{cite news|last=Reliable |first=The |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/reliable-source/2010/02/this_just_in_whitney_houston_d.html |title=Washington Post â Whitney Houston tour |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=June 13, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://itn.co.uk/254cd4c3879a0a5974a5069364ca6cfb.html |title=ITN News â Whitney cancels more shows |publisher=Itn.co.uk |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=June 13, 2010}} Houston canceled some concerts due to illness and received widespread negative reviews from fans who were disappointed in the quality of her voice and performance.
